etymologies: Old English āte, plural ātan, of unknown origin. Unlike other names of cereals (such as wheat, barley, etc.), oat is not a mass noun and may originally have denoted the individual grain, which may imply that oats were eaten in grains and not as meal

definitions: a cereal plant cultivated chiefly in cool climates and widely used for animal feed as well as human consumption.
shortDefinitions: cereal plant cultivated chiefly in cool climates

definitions: the grain yielded by this, used as food.
shortDefinitions: grain yielded by this, used as food

definitions: used in names of wild grasses related to the cultivated oat, e.g., wild oat.
shortDefinitions: used in names of wild grasses related to cultivated oat
